Cipher Nine:
We've never met, but I wanted to thank you for your handling of Watcher X on Nar Shaddaa. I know from personal experience how deceptive the man can be; the thought of him running free is mildly terrifying.
You likely aren't aware of the events that led to Watcher X's imprisonment. All I can say is that Operation: Undertow left me with scars that will never heal. I was among the lucky ones.
My people will be performing a detailed postmortem on the body. There's much to learn, and we won't build a mistake like him again.

[Message utilizes non-standard encoding. Attempted reconstruction follows.]
You helped me, I help you. Contents downloaded from Intelligence databanks and encrypted to avoid flagging by the Minders' monitoring software. Suggest you delete after reading.
More to come later.

I promised you more data. I keep my word.
It's strange, being free of Shadow Town. I'd forgotten how many different-colored suns there are.

Personality: Watcher Two is acutely aware of the significance and the limitations of her genetic enhancements--although technically adept, she struggles with rapid environmental changes that leave her unable to integrate new variables. Following her teenage difficulties, she has come to accept her programmed loyalty controls but still suffers in field operations.
Watcher Two's emotional limits are well formed. Should she become romantically engaged with a human colleague, standard support and trust benefits may arise without compromising security. Her priorities are clear.

I had to perform physical violence last night. I find it distasteful. But certainly better than being locked in a box with a bomb in my head.
I've sent you what I can, for now. If our paths intersect again, I'll see what I can do.
One other thing--there's more to Czerka Corporation's corruption than the obvious. Still working out the pattern.

Agent:
My name is Vanein Thul, and I serve with one of House Thul's reconnaissance divisions on the Alderaanian front. Moff Sarek authorized this message after a strange encounter near the Cortess estates.
My people were assessing the Killik infestation in the area--they've been building a hive in the estate proper, though they appear to be non-hostile toward our forces.
We were approached by a Cortess Joiner, who gave us a package with instructions that it be delivered to you. He mentioned something about "gratitude," and looked worryingly like the old captain of the guard.
Frankly, I'm hoping they stay to themselves in the future.
From the Baron of House Cortess

This message is sent in the name of Baron Peyar Cortess, Sword of the Castle Lands.
Although the baron has already extended his apologies to the Imperial ambassador, he also wishes to express his profound regret over the necessity of your involvement in house affairs.
Baroness Chay was a valued member of the house, and she will be mourned. Nonetheless, her action in support of enemies of the Empire cannot be forgiven.
You offered Cortess a chance at redemption when you joined our fight against the Killiks. Difficult days lie ahead, but the baron has recalled his son Pashon to Alderaan and believes together they will forge a greater future and a true partnership with the Empire.

My wife. You remain in memory.
You met with the Three. Our family is honored. Therod-Ton counsels the young.
My uncle and I record. My sister speaks to outsiders. You touched her.
Bas-Ton is gone, but you brought joy.
There is Change. Voss remains Voss.

My wife. I do not know if you hear.
I send out of tradition. I speak as a friend.
The teahouse is different. The holidays come, and we study.
Your people walk Voss-Ka. We offer tea. Some drink; I remember you. Others marry; I remember you.
Your place in the teahouse always remains. Others' hearts fill the emptiness.
Forget me. Remember Voss.

Husband:
I try to remember your face in ivory. Your portrait to hang in the teahouse.
You visited the Three, and brought our family honor.
We held my father's funeral. The sun burned. We had only leaves to bury.
My uncle loved him as a boy; now I think you knew him best.
Carry him with you, if not your wife.

Husband:
Perhaps you forget us, or wish to. Forgive this message.
I no longer serve the teahouse. In the Alien Enclave, I study. I will never be an artist.
My uncle despairs, but my husband has no family. Tradition cannot fit.
I shape my life as I shape stone.
Thank you. I leave you be.

To anyone reading this:
If you receive this message, I'm probably dead. I've got HoloNet software scanning Voss commando frequencies for problems at the teahouse; if anything comes up and I don't enter a code, the software alerts any local Imperial Intelligence contacts.
If there are problems at the teahouse, my family probably can't help you either. I don't have much in the way of resources, but anything I have is yours.
You're alone on a dangerous planet. Good luck.
Moff Zamar Killed on Corellian Front

CORONET CITY -- Moff Alvon Zamar was killed today in Labor Valley on the Corellian battlefront. The decorated military commander was traveling in a light skyhopper that was apparently forced to land after straying into enemy territory. The Moff and his entourage were eliminated by Republic forces shortly thereafter.
Moff Zamar was not in direct command of Corellian troops, and his loss will not affect the Core Worlds strategy. He will be remembered as a beloved leader and a courageous soldier. He is survived by his five children.

My team made it back to the Tears of Taris intact. I can't say I enjoyed our encounter in Labor Valley, but these are trying times for us all.
I'm returning to Imperial space shortly to deliver my report. We'll see what becomes of it, but I urge you to keep the contents secure. Our troops are in far greater disarray than the Republic knows; we cannot afford for our enemies to realize their advantage.
On a personal note--I'd like to assure you that I did not support the dissolution of Imperial Intelligence. I've had my share of disagreements with the Minister, but the organization served a purpose.
This is all the aid I can provide. Best of luck.

Legate:
I've been getting reports from inside the Empire. Word is things are awfully messy with Imperial Intelligence dissolved; no one's keeping order anymore, and that means everyone's trying to grab power.
I understand you've got a reputation but no authority--which puts you in everyone's trigger sights. You want to be a reformer, be careful. Maybe lay low awhile, if that's your style.
On this side of the fence, the new Supreme Chancellor is pushing a more aggressive military strategy. Maybe it'll lead to a quick and easy peace, but it could get very bloody for both sides. I'll do what I can, but I'm in a tricky spot myself.
This war may get worse before it gets better.

To all former Imperial Intelligence personnel:
By now, most of you have been reassigned to departments in need of your services. To those who have yet to receive final instructions or who have been awaiting contact in the field, I apologize and urge you to remain patient and vigilant.
I regret these circumstances, but should any of you feel abandoned, I remind you that you understood the risks inherent in joining Imperial Intelligence. We agreed to serve the Empire, and we have done so to the best of our abilities.
Take pride in our accomplishments, and do not forget your training. Until our successor organization arises, you are needed more than ever. You are all that holds the Empire together.

so what's lousy about hyperspace? it's really freaking dull. you know how many times i cleaned my guns last trip?
before the next time we fly, i want the liquor cabinet restocked (with SOMETHING NEW this time), at least thirty new premium HoloNet feeds, unrestricted turret access and the right to bring three good-looking young people of my choice aboard.
if you argue in any way, i will shoot 2V-R8 or never again pay a late-night surprise visit to the captain's quarters. probably the first, but i'm betting you wont risk it.

you probably dont want to go into the engine room for a while. power surge was totally my fault. don't ask.
next time we're near the purse worlds, remind me that we need to go to koru neimoidia. obv not a big fan of neimoidians, but you've got too much money and we can blow through a few thousand credits on clubs and gambling somewhere new.
besides, we need a vacation. you and me, together. NO MOFFS OR DARTHS ALLOWED.
we can pack vector in a glass jar with air holes if you insist.

here are some things for you to work on.
1) find us bigger and badder things to kill.
you've been doing good on this for a while, but sometimes i think you're doing this for the empire and not just for me. for example, the banking clan has awesome security. wouldn't blowing vaults and getting rich be better than dying to save some imperial stockboy?
2) figure out where this war is going.
seriously, it's getting bad. if you really have to fight for them, make sure you know what you're doing. you shouldn't be taking orders from anyone anymore.
3) make doctor lokin stop practicing huttese.
it's getting on my nerves.

My new goal: Find someone who can hold a conversation about things other than a) war / politics, b) spycraft and c) fun crimes and how to celebrate them (just once, Kaliyo...)
I will find this amazing person by taking on a well-documented cover identity to make myself seem vaguely normal. If kidnapping is necessary, I will reluctantly act.
Lastly, we will invite this person to a dinner party. Vector and Doctor Lokin can come if they behave. But just once, we can all do something that doesn't end in a firefight.
Agreed? No?
Love you.

Last night, I had a dream where I looked in the mirror and my face was covered in red. When I tried to rub it off, it smeared into a Sith tattoo. I woke up, and I swear I was floating just a little.
This morning, all I could think about was my father. Dead because of me. I miss him.
We're living in a different Empire, these days. I want to think that in a hundred years, no one will have to go through things like this.
Promise me that'll work out, and I won't angst until then?
One hundred years. Ready? Go.

I didn't forget. You still haven't told me when it is, and the one time I asked around, Kaliyo was the only one who gave me an answer and she was clearly lying.
So I'm taking this as a challenge to break into your personal files. If I electrocute myself, then I'm a failure and the blame will go on you, my mentor.
I did buy you a book of Chiss poetry. A real book--bound sheets and everything. You may never see it.
Love you.

While meditating in the cargo bay, we suddenly realized the nature of the vessel around us. It was as if the great metallic hull had been made of glass until that moment, when it turned opaque and became all we saw.
Every star system your vessel travels through changes it. Radiation from a hundred suns falls across the plating like rain, leaving microscopic craters in the metal sheets. Every bolt and missile aimed at us in rage or resignation alters the heartbeat of the engine.
The Song of the Universe is with us.
We are pleased to make the vessel our home with you.

The others don't speak much to SCORPIO. Neither do we, frankly--she has little interest in emerging from the engine room or speaking to "lesser intellects." But we think we're starting to understand her.
We found her interfacing with the HoloNet recently, and she told us what she saw--a thousand people, a thousand stories and places all at once. We told her we experience much the same thing when we commune with the nest.
She watched us for some time, and we thought we'd reached her. Then she told us, "But you are not the will of the nest" and turned away.
We have come to respect SCORPIO, but we wonder what she will become.

There are days when we realize how little we know you.
For every Joiner who has ever joined the nest, we remember her youth, her first spring and her birthdays and her intimate moments. We remember his dreams and his childhood fears.
We know the words you've spoken, your scent and your taste, your triumphs and your sacrifices. We know there's no other being whose song we'd rather hear as the days pass.
We do not know more than that. But it is enough, and we are glad.

Agent:
I assume you confirmed Karrels Javis's death? It appears someone has taken an interest in his offspring. See forward below.
To: Keeper From: Watcher Three Subject: Follow-up on Karrels Javis
Standard monitoring of Vargai Javis (brother of Serjil, son of Karrels) aboard the hospital ship Anodyne has revealed an item of interest. Vargai was recovering from his injuries in a kolto tank when a mercenary team boarded the hospital vessel. The mercenaries then extracted Vargai and the kolto tank.
Vargai's current location is unknown. Party responsible is also unknown--did our asset on Hutta verify Karrels's execution? Karrels had means and motives to relocate his only surviving son, but I was told he'd been eliminated.

Agent:
With Karrels Javis's death, his surviving son is a potential loose end. I'm clearing you for status updates in case matters get complicated. See forward below.
To: Keeper From: Watcher Three Subject: Follow-up on Karrels Javis
We believe Vargai Javis (brother of Serjil, son of Karrels) is the only individual with motive and means to perform a more thorough investigation into Karrels Javis's death.
Vargai is currently recovering from injuries aboard the hospital ship Anodyne, but we can arrange for an asset to alter the chemical balance of his kolto tank. His recovery time can be extended indefinitely, and he can be removed as an active threat without drawing suspicion.

Agent:
In order to mitigate any public concern over the death of Samara Mindak, we will be announcing her complicity in the crimes of her father. Your execution of her at the Nexus Room cantina has been ruled appropriate and necessary for public safety.
In addition, Imperial Intelligence has placed a public investigation notice on all friends and associates of the Mindak family. Until we have completed our interrogation of these individuals, their credit accounts, transport passes and Citizen's Security Clearances will be frozen. Previous failures to report the Mindaks will be considered official derelictions of vigilance.
We appreciate your thoroughness in these matters.

Agent:
Following your recent encounter with Samara Mindak at the Nexus Room cantina, Imperial Intelligence sent two interviewers (operating under Minder supervision) to debrief her at her apartments in Kaas City. She has offered her full cooperation and provided valuable insight into her father's dissident activities.
The physical damage she sustained during your questioning appears to be moderate; we estimate a two-month recovery time. Psychological damage is more severe, and she will be observed closely to ensure that any instability doesn't manifest in dissident behavior.
We are grateful for your assistance.

Agent:
Following your recent encounter with Samara Mindak at the Nexus Room cantina, Imperial Intelligence sent two interviewers (operating under Minder supervision) to debrief her at her apartments in Kaas City. She has offered her full cooperation and provided valuable insight into her father's dissident activities.
In addition, Mindak expressed her interest in your personal circumstances and her gratitude for your intervention in her father's operation. She extends an invitation to you to visit, should her family's workshops reopen after the current crisis.
She requested we pass along the attached item to show her sincerity. It has been scanned and logged in accordance with regulations.

So, I've been running for my life, hiding from Imperials and anyone who might've survived the ghost cell.
What've you been up to?
Not sure if you'll ever see this, but there are things I never got to say. I should've died on Tatooine. I should hate Imperial Intelligence with all my heart.
I didn't, and I don't, and I don't know how to keep fighting. I'm not giving up, I just... don't know.
Stay alive, okay?

Cipher Nine:
We sent a cleanup team to what's left of the ghost cell village on Tatooine. I wanted to alert you that--along with the expected links to the Eagle's network--we found something strange.
The Old Man spent decades teaching his followers, and it looks like a few outsiders unconnected to terrorism trained under him as well.
The weird part is, some of the data on his students has been wiped. The ghost cell may be gone, but someone's out there with all the Old Man's techniques.

KAAS CITY -- The return of Darth Jadus to the Dark Council was a moment of triumph for the Empire. Once thought lost aboard the starship Dominator, his resurrection coincided with the inferno that was "Eradication Day."
With hundreds of thousands dead--many dissidents and traitors, others unfortunates caught in the war between Lord Jadus and the late Eagle's terrorist network--a time for rebuilding has arrived.
Walking among a crowd of wounded officers and starving slaves, Lord Jadus promised to spread the knowledge of the Sith Order and bring strength to the wretched. His "ambassadors of fire" will lead public ceremonies starting tomorrow for all willing to attend.

hello. you wouldn't remember me, but i was on Darth Jadus's ship when you attacked. i was one of the people he invited to the Dominator as his guests.
we all thought we were special. then most of us died and the Master taught us to see the world like he does.
i don't remember most of what happened after that
when you rescued us, the doctors helped me stop hurting myself and other people. i asked about you, and wanted to say thanks.
that's all.

To all field personnel:
Given the recent death of the Eagle and the dismantling of his Eradicator network, Imperial Intelligence will propose that the Citadel stand down from high alert as of 05:00 tomorrow.
It is vital that we show confidence that the dissident problem is contained. The military relies on us to protect it from internal threats. But cleanup operations will take years to complete, and we must remain vigilant.
We have achieved a tremendous victory at great cost. Now we must ensure our enemy does not return and grant our attention to any threats we have neglected.

Legate:
I'm writing you from a medcenter on Coruscant. They've got me on a lot of painkillers, so sorry if I don't make a lot of sense.
I can't imagine how you feel, working with the SIS. It took a lot of courage for you to come over, and now it must seem like we abused your trust. Ardun's not a bad man, but he thought he needed to play it safe and keep you under control.
Well, maybe he's right and maybe he isn't. Not really my place to argue while I'm on duty, but I'm sure not on duty anymore.
You saved my life, and it dawns on me that you didn't have to. You've got a good heart. The Republic is where you were meant to be.
Thanks for everything. Buy you a drink when I'm out of rehab?

Legate:
Sent this to the rest of the team already. You're new, but Chance respected you, and you were part of his last mission. Hope it means something.
To: Ardun Kothe, Wheel, Hunter From: Saber Subject: Saying Goodbye to Chance
By now, all of you know that Chance didn't make it back from Taris. He told me once that he was terrified of dying. But he said what scared him worse was dying and no one knowing or caring--dying forgotten, like so many in this business do.
He was a brave soldier, a patriot, an animal-lover and a hilarious drunk. I'll miss him.
I'm sending around his personal effects. Anything left goes to his dad.
where would I be without you?

I'm kind of surprised you didn't betray me. Chance pass you by, or did you really think I'd fit into your Empire?
Things are working out, though. Not that everyone here wants to take orders from an ex-Jedi, but kill enough idiots and people learn their lesson. I've found a nice little planet where my Nikto can join me. They'll love it here.
Did I mention Darth Serevin offered his protection? I'll be a Sith Lord in no time.
No more rules. I'll help your people so long as me and my cult can do what we want. Maybe I'll even show you my appreciation....

The SIS doesn't know I'm writing this. I'm not supposed to have access to the comms, but a little mind trick does wonders. They'll find out, though, and afterwards I'll get a long talking-to from the counselors.
You know how many counselors are on SIS staff? No wonder the Republic is losing the war.
Better to be here than going crazy on Taris, I guess. And I can't face the Jedi after everything. So maybe you were right.
I miss the Nikto so much. You don't know what it's like to have people see you as a hero--someone to love and obey. I'll come back to them. I swear I will.
For now, I'm here. Earning "redemption." Guess that's how it goes.

Got this from the sector station chief. Thought you might want to know about the fallout. This isn't disapproval or judgment--just a heads-up.
To: Ardun Kothe From: [redacted] Subject: Ki Sazen's Cult
To no one's surprise, killing that crazy Jedi caused its own share of problems. The Nikto who worshiped her are blaming the Republic and demanding justice; if we don't produce a scapegoat soon, they'll go on a rampage.
Even if we do, the cult's going to live on, with only Ki Sazen's ramblings to guide them. Maybe we can get them out of the system somehow.

To my friend the Cipher agent:
We worked together for only a short time on Hoth, but you earned the respect of myself and my crew and I wanted to share my good news.
As of today, I am retiring from the Imperial military and purchasing the commissions of my most trusted subordinates. I'm eager to spend old age surrounded by luxury.
I'm certain you understand your role in this decision, and I see a bright future ahead of you. Attached is a taste of what you might achieve, following my example.
By the way: It's a pity about the Chiss Defense Force. I hear their base was overrun by pirates and every last man butchered. If only they were more like you.
Regarding the Death of Admiral Davos

Cipher Nine:
I am writing in regards to the recent death of Admiral Layek Davos on Hoth. It took me some time to confirm your presence; I still don't know your exact role.
Layek Davos was a brilliant admiral and as corrupt as they come. I will not mourn him. In fact, I have added a commendation to your record for your part in stopping his illegal operation.
But I also warn you: When Imperial Intelligence and the Chiss Defense Force purge corruption from the military without consulting the Moffs, it puts our readiness at risk. Replacing Admiral Davos is not an easy task, and now we must do so on short notice.
Remember that the Empire must act as one.

I have decided to keep my walls bare, here in the domicile to which I've been told I've retired.
It's quite a thing to find yourself at once no longer required and yet too vital to cast aside. My days are spent in pursuit of a better dejarik strategy. Better that than to allow languor to become the keeper of my thoughts.
Overheard a curious story about an old adversary resurfacing to play his games with his toys; I sometimes wonder if you were drawn into this particular shroud of deceit and how you might have handled yourself.
I hope you'll forgive the personal nature of this message. The truth is, I've always admired your intelligence.
A raveled knot of undue secrecy

I've had a visitor.
A figure I will not name wished to see if I had been longing for any particular amenities for my retirement home. The stranger looked around, contemplated, and finally opined that there were nine ways to improve the place. Nothing was asked of me in exchange. I declined the offer, and my would-be benefactor departed.
It was a strange encounter; I should think I would not want a return visit. If you ever find yourself presented with a gift from such a character, you should disintegrate all your possessions and promptly withdraw to parts unknown.
I may not contact you again after this, so I hope that you heed my moderately dark counsel in this matter.

Downright fascinating, what's been transpiring lately.
Unease must be creeping up through your insides, but don't worry; I'm not a factor to be concerned with in all this Revanite business. I'm more of a spectator, and you've proven yourself a most intriguing participant--enough so that I thought it might be fun to reach out, say "hi."
On the subject of communications, I've been following some chatter amongst the traitors in your midst following Darth Arkous's death. They know they can't touch you and they are thoroughly incensed about it. It's really quite amusing.
Regardless, you should remain aware that whatever harm they can't bring to you, they'll surely visit upon your Sith friend once they find her. I wonder how long she can keep to the shadows....
Hey, this was fun after all. I'll have to do it again sometime.
Seems almost pointless to mention, but I had considered asking you to give the old man my regards. Don't bother; I'm sure if he's alive he knows I'm back in business by now. And that, for me, is satisfaction enough.

OFFICIAL ENCODED IMPERIAL CORRESPONDENCE SENSITIVITY: EXTREME
If you are receiving this message, you presently enjoy some manner of clearance by order of an Imperial institution no longer in existence. As part of the ongoing effort to officially dissolve this institution, the clearance granted to you under its charter is hereby revoked by order of the Dark Council. Clearance afforded you by other means, listed below, will remain in effect for the duration of its natural term:
: SPECIAL CLEARANCE ::: AUTH. DARTH MARR
: SPECIAL IMMUNITY ::: AUTH. DARTH MARR
This message was compiled and distributed by automated courier. If you believe you have received this message in error, disregard. Replies will not be received. No further correspondence regarding this matter will be sent.
For the Empire.
